title: Suffixes — -tion and -ness
description: Students learn how the suffixes -tion (turns a verb into a noun meaning 'the act of') and -ness (turns an adjective into a noun meaning 'the state of') change word meanings and parts of speech.
instructions:
1. Introduce the concept of a suffix: letters added to the END of a word that change its meaning and often its part of speech.
2. Present -tion: turns verbs into nouns. Educate → education. Celebrate → celebration.
3. Present -ness: turns adjectives into nouns. Happy → happiness. Dark → darkness.
4. The child builds words with suffix cards and base word cards.
5. Notice spelling changes: educate drops the 'e' before -tion; happy changes 'y' to 'i' before -ness.
6. Write sentences using new words.

slides.heading: Suffixes
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our super cool word-building book! It tells us we're going to learn about something called "suffixes," which are like little word endings. We'll discover how "-tion" and "-ness" can change words to mean "the act of" doing something or "the state of" being something.

items: Base word cards: educate, celebrate, create, decorate, imagine, invent, pollinate, happy, sad, dark, kind, fair, soft, good, lonely, ill, neat, weak
slides.setup_instructions: Write suffix cards on one color and base word cards on another. Sort base words into two groups: verbs (for -tion) and adjectives (for -ness). Have grammar symbols ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, time to get our word-building tools ready! You see those colorful cards? We have suffix cards with "-tion" and "-ness" on them, and other cards with "base words" like "happy" or "educate." We'll also need your vocabulary journal and a pencil to write down all the awesome new words we make, and some special grammar symbol cards too.

slides.text: Prefixes go at the beginning of words. Suffixes go at the END! Today we learn two powerful suffixes that change verbs and adjectives into nouns.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important rule for our word adventure! Think of prefixes like a little hat that goes on the *front* of a word, but suffixes are like shoes that go on the *end*. Today, we're focusing on those word-ending shoes, called suffixes, that help us change words that show action into words that name things!

slides.text: The suffix -tion turns a verb (action word) into a noun (thing word). 'Celebrate' is something you DO (verb). 'Celebration' is a THING (noun) — the act of celebrating. Try: create → creation, educate → education, imagine → imagination.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's where the "-tion" magic happens! When you add "-tion" to the end of a word that shows you doing something (like "celebrate"), it turns it into a word that names that action (like "celebration"). It's like turning an action into a *thing* you can talk about! So, "educate" becomes "education," which is the act of teaching.

slides.text: The suffix -ness turns an adjective (describing word) into a noun. 'Happy' describes how you feel. 'Happiness' is the STATE of being happy — it is a thing you can talk about. Try: dark → darkness, kind → kindness, sad → sadness.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's look at "-ness"! This suffix is for words that describe something, like "happy." When you add "-ness" to words like "happy," it turns them into a noun that means the *state* of being that way. So, "happy" becomes "happiness," which is the feeling or state of being happy. It's like turning a feeling into something you can name!

slides.prompt: Build as many -tion and -ness words as you can with the cards. In your vocabulary journal, create a two-column page: -tion words on the left, -ness words on the right. Write the base word, the new word, and the part of speech change (verb→noun or adjective→noun). Write 4 sentences using your new words.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to build some words! Grab your suffix cards and base word cards, and let's see how many new words we can create. We'll sort them into "-tion" words and "-ness" words in your journal, and then write some sentences using our fantastic new words. You've got this!

slides.text: Suffixes are magic — they transform words from one part of speech to another! When you see -tion at the end of a word, you know it is a noun meaning 'the act of' something. When you see -ness, it is a noun meaning 'the state of' something.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child form correct words with -tion and -ness and explain how the suffix changes the part of speech?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the amazing words we made! You learned how "-tion" turns action words into nouns for the *act of* something, and "-ness" turns describing words into nouns for the *state of* being something. You're like a word wizard, transforming words with those suffixes!

parent_notes: Suffixes are more complex than prefixes because they often change the part of speech AND require spelling changes. Focus on understanding the meaning shift first; spelling patterns come with practice. The grammar symbol connection (verb symbol → noun symbol) makes the part-of-speech change visible. Common spelling changes: drop final 'e' before -tion, change 'y' to 'i' before -ness.

title: Subtracting Like Fractions — Fraction Insets
description: Students learn to subtract fractions with the same denominator using fraction insets. They physically remove fraction pieces and record the subtraction equations.
instructions:
1. Review adding like fractions (quick warm-up).
2. Introduce subtraction: 3/4 - 1/4. Place 3 fourth-pieces in the circle, then remove 1. Count remaining: 2/4.
3. Explain: Same rule as addition — keep the denominator, subtract the numerators.
4. Practice with various denominators.
5. Solve word problems involving fraction subtraction.
6. Mix addition and subtraction problems.

slides.heading: Subtracting Fractions
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is the title for our math adventure today! It tells us we're going to learn how to take away pieces of the same whole, like if you have 3 slices of a pizza cut into 4 equal parts, and you eat one. We'll be using special fraction pieces to help us see exactly what's happening.

slides.setup_instructions: Set out fraction insets. Prepare 8-10 subtraction problems and 3-4 word problems. Open math journal to a fresh page titled 'Subtracting Fractions.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's get our tools ready for subtracting fractions! We've got these cool fraction insets – they're like puzzle pieces that show us parts of a whole circle. You'll also need your math journal and a pencil, maybe some colored pencils too, for drawing. Oh, and there are some word problems on cards, like little math mysteries to solve!

slides.text: Quick warm-up: 2/5 + 1/5 = ? (3/5). Great! Now let us learn subtraction. If you can add fractions, you can subtract them — same rule, different operation.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like a quick warm-up to get our brains ready. It reminds us how we added fractions, like adding 2 fifths and 1 fifth to get 3 fifths. Now, we're going to do something very similar but instead of putting pieces together, we'll be taking them away, and the rule for the bottom number stays exactly the same!

slides.text: Place 3 fourth-pieces in the circle frame. We have 3/4. Now take away 1 piece. How many are left? 2 pieces out of 4 = 2/4. Write: 3/4 − 1/4 = 2/4. The denominator stays the same!
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's where the subtraction magic begins! We're going to start with 3 out of 4 pieces, which we write as 3/4. Imagine you have 3 slices of a pizza cut into 4 pieces. Now, we take away just one of those pieces. See how we have 2 pieces left? That means we have 2/4 of the pizza left, and we write it down like this: 3/4 - 1/4 = 2/4.

slides.text: Try 5/6 − 2/6. Place 5 sixth-pieces. Remove 2. Count remaining: 3 sixths. 5/6 − 2/6 = 3/6. Word problem: 'Mom made a pie cut into 8 slices. The family ate 5/8. How much is left?' 8/8 − 5/8 = 3/8.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to try another problem together using our fraction pieces. We'll start with 5 out of 6 pieces and then take away 2 of them. See how that leaves us with 3 pieces? So, 5/6 minus 2/6 equals 3/6. The slide also has a fun word problem about a pie – if the family ate 5 out of 8 slices, we can figure out how much pie is still there!

slides.prompt: Solve with fraction insets and record: 1) 3/4 − 1/4, 2) 5/6 − 3/6, 3) 7/8 − 4/8, 4) 4/5 − 1/5, 5) 6/10 − 3/10. Word problems: 6) 'I had 3/4 of a pizza. I ate 1/4. How much is left?' 7) 'A jar was 5/6 full. We used 2/6. How full is it now?' Draw each problem!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our chance to be super fraction detectives! You'll use your fraction pieces to show each problem, like starting with 3 fourths and taking away 1 fourth. Then, you'll write down the answer and even draw a picture of it in your journal. There are some tricky word problems too, but you can solve them by drawing them out just like we did with the pie!

slides.text: Adding and subtracting fractions follow the same rule: keep the denominator, add or subtract the numerators. You have mastered both! Tomorrow, we introduce something new: mixed numbers.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child subtract like fractions using the insets and solve a subtraction word problem?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! We learned that adding and subtracting fractions with the same bottom number is super easy because that bottom number, called the denominator, just stays put. You just add or subtract the top numbers. You've become a fraction subtraction whiz, and tomorrow we'll learn about even bigger fractions called mixed numbers!

parent_notes: Fraction subtraction with like denominators follows the same logic as addition, so most children pick it up quickly. The physical act of removing pieces from the inset makes the concept concrete. If the child finds it too easy, challenge them with problems that result in zero (3/3 − 3/3 = 0) or with missing parts (? − 2/5 = 1/5). These extend thinking naturally.

title: Ancient Egypt — Hieroglyphics and the Rosetta Stone
description: Students learn about the Egyptian writing system (hieroglyphics), its decline, and how the Rosetta Stone unlocked its secrets. They practice reading simple hieroglyphic symbols and learn about Jean-Francois Champollion.
instructions:
1. Review hieroglyphics from the cartouche activity.
2. Explain: hieroglyphics were used for over 3,000 years, then forgotten after Egypt became part of the Roman Empire.
3. Tell the story of the Rosetta Stone: found in 1799 by Napoleon's soldiers, same text in three scripts.
4. Tell the story of Champollion: the young genius who cracked the code.
5. The child writes a message in hieroglyphics for someone to decode.
6. Discuss: What if we lost the ability to read English?

slides.heading: Hieroglyphics
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into Ancient Egypt's secret writing! It tells us we're going to explore something called hieroglyphics and a super important discovery called the Rosetta Stone. Think of it like the cover of a mystery book – it makes you wonder what secrets are inside!

items: Image of the Rosetta Stone (printed or in book)
slides.setup_instructions: Display the Rosetta Stone image and hieroglyphic chart. Have drawing paper ready for writing messages. Open the history journal to a new page.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our explorer gear ready! We need this chart that shows us all the cool picture-symbols the Egyptians used, kind of like their alphabet. We also need a picture of the Rosetta Stone, which is like a giant clue! You'll also need some paper to write on, your history journal to keep notes, and pencils and colors to make your writing look amazing. Go grab all your supplies so we're ready to go!

slides.text: Hieroglyphics were one of the oldest writing systems in the world. The word means 'sacred carvings.' Egyptians used them for over 3,000 years — on temple walls, tombs, and papyrus scrolls. But by 400 AD, no one could read them anymore.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, imagine writing that lasted for *thousands* of years – that's how long people used hieroglyphics! The Egyptians carved these picture-words everywhere, like on big buildings and secret tombs. But then, after a long, long time, people stopped understanding them, and it was like their whole history became a giant puzzle no one could solve.

slides.text: In 1799, French soldiers in Egypt found a large stone with the SAME message written in three scripts: hieroglyphics, Demotic (everyday Egyptian), and Greek. Since scholars could read Greek, they had a key to unlock hieroglyphics! This stone is called the Rosetta Stone.
slides.mascot_explanation: Then, one day, some soldiers digging around found a really big, special rock! What was so amazing about it was that it had the *same* message written in three different ways: in those cool hieroglyphics, in another Egyptian writing, and in Greek. Since people *could* still read Greek, it was like finding a secret decoder ring to figure out what the hieroglyphics meant!

slides.text: A young Frenchman named Jean-Francois Champollion spent years studying the Rosetta Stone. In 1822, he finally cracked the code! He realized hieroglyphics used both pictures for sounds AND pictures for whole words. He could read Ancient Egyptian again!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, meet Jean-Francois Champollion – he was like a super-detective for ancient languages! He looked at that Rosetta Stone for years and years, and he finally figured out the secret. He realized that some picture-symbols stood for sounds, like our letters, and others stood for whole words. Because of him, we can now read all the amazing stories the Egyptians wrote so long ago!

slides.prompt: In your history journal, write the Rosetta Stone story: who found it, what was on it, and how Champollion decoded it. Then write a secret message in hieroglyphics (at least 3 words) for someone in your family to decode using the alphabet chart.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the historian and the code-maker! First, in your journal, write down the story of the Rosetta Stone – who found it, what was special about it, and how Champollion figured it out. Then, use your hieroglyphic chart to write a secret message of at least three words. It’s like sending a secret note that only someone with the chart can read!

slides.text: The Rosetta Stone is now in the British Museum in London. Thanks to it, we can read the words ancient Egyptians wrote thousands of years ago. Writing truly is one of humanity's greatest inventions — just like the Third Great Lesson taught us!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child tell the story of the Rosetta Stone and explain why it was important for understanding hieroglyphics?
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't it incredible that this stone, found by accident, helped us understand a whole ancient civilization? Because of the Rosetta Stone, we can still hear the voices of people who lived thousands of years ago! It shows us just how powerful and important writing is for sharing stories and history across time.

parent_notes: The Rosetta Stone story is one of the great detective stories of history. Champollion was just 31 when he cracked the code, which makes him relatable to young learners. This connects beautifully to the Third Great Lesson (Coming of Writing). If the child is interested, explore other undeciphered scripts like Linear A — mysteries still waiting to be solved!

title: Africa — Physical Features and the Great Rift Valley
description: Students explore the physical geography of Africa: the Sahara Desert, Great Rift Valley, Mount Kilimanjaro, Congo Rainforest, and major rivers. They focus on the Great Rift Valley as a tectonic feature.
instructions:
1. Show a physical map of Africa.
2. Identify major features: Sahara, Sahel, Congo Basin, Great Rift Valley, Kilimanjaro, Atlas Mountains.
3. Explain the Great Rift Valley: a crack in the Earth's crust where tectonic plates are pulling apart.
4. Connect to Q1 tectonic plates lesson.
5. Identify major rivers: Nile, Congo, Niger, Zambezi.
6. The child creates a physical features map of Africa.

slides.heading: Africa
slides.subheading: Physical Features and the Great Rift Valley
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the cover page for our adventure in Africa! It tells us we're going to learn all about the amazing landforms and natural wonders on this huge continent, like deserts, mountains, and a giant valley that's actually a crack in the Earth!

items: Colored pencils (brown, green, blue, yellow, white)
Clay or playdough (optional for relief map)
slides.setup_instructions: Display a large physical map of Africa. Have the atlas open to the Africa section. Prepare drawing materials and optional clay for a relief map.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is our treasure chest of tools for exploring Africa! We've got a big map to show us everything, an atlas or globe like a super-powered magnifying glass, paper and colorful pencils to draw with, and even some playdough if we want to make our map bumpy and real like the land! Go grab everything with a grown-up so we're ready to go!

slides.text: Africa is the second-largest continent and has incredible variety! The north has the Sahara — the world's largest hot desert. Below it is the Sahel, a semi-dry grassland. Central Africa has the Congo Rainforest — the second-largest in the world.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, Africa is so big and has so many different kinds of places! This step tells us about the super hot Sahara Desert way up north, then a drier grassy area called the Sahel, and a giant, super-green rainforest in the middle called the Congo Rainforest – almost as big as the Amazon rainforest!

slides.text: The Great Rift Valley is a massive crack in the Earth stretching from Lebanon in Asia all the way to Mozambique in southeastern Africa — over 4,000 miles! It was formed by tectonic plates pulling apart. Remember our Q1 lesson on tectonic plates? This is where you can SEE them at work!
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for something amazing – the Great Rift Valley! Imagine the ground cracking open, like a giant puzzle piece breaking apart. That's what's happening here because huge pieces of the Earth's skin, called tectonic plates, are slowly pulling away from each other, just like we learned about before!

slides.text: Africa has incredible peaks: Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania is the tallest mountain in Africa at 19,341 feet — and it has snow on top even though it is near the equator! The continent also has 4 of the world's great rivers: the Nile, Congo, Niger, and Zambezi (with Victoria Falls).
slides.mascot_explanation: Africa isn't just flat land; it has some super tall mountains, like Mount Kilimanjaro, which is so tall it has snow on top even though it's close to the warm equator! Plus, it has some of the longest rivers in the whole world, like the famous Nile River, where ancient civilizations grew.

slides.prompt: Create a physical features map of Africa. Label and color: Sahara Desert (yellow), Congo Rainforest (dark green), Great Rift Valley (red line), Mount Kilimanjaro (brown with white peak), Atlas Mountains, Nile River, Congo River, Niger River, Zambezi River, Lake Victoria, and Lake Tanganyika.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the map maker! You're going to draw your own map of Africa and color in all the cool places we've talked about, like the yellow Sahara Desert, the green Congo Rainforest, and draw a red line for the giant Great Rift Valley. Don't forget to add the tall Mount Kilimanjaro and the big rivers too!

slides.text: Africa has every type of landscape: deserts, rainforests, mountains, valleys, rivers, and savannas. The Great Rift Valley shows us that the Earth is still changing — tectonic plates never stop moving! Next lesson, we will explore Africa's countries and people.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate at least 5 major physical features of Africa on a map and explain what causes the Great Rift Valley?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You've created a fantastic map showing all of Africa's amazing landscapes, from deserts to rainforests to that incredible Great Rift Valley. It's so cool to think that the Earth is always moving and changing, especially seeing how that giant crack formed right before our eyes on the map!

parent_notes: Africa is often poorly taught in Western curricula. This lesson focuses on physical geography, which is objective and awe-inspiring. The Great Rift Valley connection to Q1 tectonic plates reinforces spiral learning. If the child makes a clay relief map, it makes the topography tangible. Mount Kilimanjaro's snow near the equator is a great discussion starter about altitude and temperature.

title: Read Aloud — The Rosetta Stone and Hieroglyphic Decoding
description: Read aloud about the discovery and decoding of the Rosetta Stone, reinforcing today's history lesson through narrative storytelling and discussion.
instructions:
1. Review what we learned in history about hieroglyphics.
2. Read a chapter or passage about the Rosetta Stone discovery.
3. Discuss Champollion as a character: What drove him? How did he feel when he cracked the code?
4. Compare hieroglyphics to our alphabet: similarities and differences.
5. The child writes a journal entry from Champollion's perspective.
6. Add new vocabulary words to the journal.

slides.heading: Cracking the Code
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is called "Cracking the Code" and it tells us we're going to learn all about the Rosetta Stone through a story. It's like we're going to become super detectives trying to figure out a mystery from a long, long time ago!

items: Egypt read-aloud book or separate Rosetta Stone book
slides.setup_instructions: Bookmark the relevant chapter. If your Egypt book does not cover the Rosetta Stone in detail, supplement with another source.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this part, we need a few things to help us on our adventure. We'll need a book to read about the Rosetta Stone, and then a special journal where you'll write down your thoughts, plus another journal for new words, and a pencil to write with. Make sure you have your grown-up help you gather these!

slides.text: We learned about hieroglyphics and the Rosetta Stone in history today. Now let us hear the full story through our read-aloud. Listen for details we did not cover in the lesson.
slides.mascot_explanation: We already talked about hieroglyphics in history class, those cool picture-words the ancient Egyptians used. Now, we're going to read a story that tells us how people figured out what those pictures really meant, so listen carefully for any new and exciting details!

slides.text: Read the chapter aloud. Pause to discuss: 'Imagine you found a stone with writing you could not read. How would you feel? What would you try first?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to read the story! As we read, imagine you found a secret message in a language no one understands – how would that make you feel, excited or confused? Think about what you would do first to try and solve the puzzle.

slides.text: After reading, discuss Champollion: 'He started learning languages as a child and knew over a dozen by the time he decoded hieroglyphics at age 31. What does his story tell us about the power of curiosity and persistence?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This next part is all about a super smart guy named Champollion who was amazing at languages. He learned so many languages when he was young, and he never gave up on figuring out the hieroglyphics. What does that tell you about how important it is to keep trying and stay curious?

slides.prompt: Write a journal entry as if you are Champollion on the day you finally cracked the hieroglyphic code. How do you feel? What was the hardest part? What will you do now? Write at least one paragraph in your reading journal.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to use your imagination! You're going to pretend you are Champollion on the exact day he finally understood the hieroglyphics. Write in your journal about how happy and excited you feel, what was the trickiest part, and what you want to do next with this amazing discovery.

slides.text: Champollion's discovery opened a window into 3,000 years of Egyptian history. Without the Rosetta Stone, we would not know the names of the pharaohs or the stories on the temple walls. One stone changed everything!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write a perspective journal entry that demonstrates understanding of the Rosetta Stone's significance?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! Champollion's discovery was a huge deal because it unlocked the secrets of ancient Egypt, letting us understand their history and stories. Just one stone helped us learn about pharaohs and temples from thousands of years ago – how amazing is that!

parent_notes: The perspective writing activity builds empathy and historical thinking. Accept the child's interpretation of Champollion's emotions — there is no wrong answer. If the child is reluctant to write a full paragraph, let them write a diary entry with shorter sentences or draw a comic strip of the moment of discovery. The key is emotional engagement with the historical event.

title: Suffixes — -ful and -less
description: Students learn the suffixes -ful (full of) and -less (without). They discover that these suffixes create opposites and build words that describe qualities.
instructions:
1. Review -tion and -ness from yesterday.
2. Introduce -ful: means 'full of.' Care → careful (full of care). Hope → hopeful.
3. Introduce -less: means 'without.' Care → careless (without care). Hope → hopeless.
4. Discover the pattern: -ful and -less often create opposites! Careful/careless, hopeful/hopeless.
5. Build word pairs and use them in contrasting sentences.
6. Add to the vocabulary journal suffix section.

slides.heading: Suffixes
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our word adventure today! It's showing us the two special word endings, called suffixes, we're going to learn about: "-ful" and "-less." We'll discover how they change words and what they mean, which is pretty neat!

items: Base word cards: care, hope, help, thought, thank, rest, power, fear, harm, taste, use, pain, cheer, grace, color, end
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare suffix and base word cards. Sort base words into those that work with -ful only, -less only, and both (creating opposite pairs). Open vocabulary journal to the suffix section.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we need for our word-building mission! We've got these little cards with our base words like "care" and "hope," and other cards with our suffixes "-ful" and "-less." We also need our special vocabulary journal and some pencils to write everything down. Make sure you have all these ready to go!

slides.text: Yesterday we learned -tion and -ness. Today we meet two suffixes that are opposites of each other! The suffix -ful means 'full of.' Cheerful means full of cheer. Colorful means full of color.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yesterday, we played with word endings like "-tion" and "-ness," remember? Well, today we're meeting two new friends, "-ful" and "-less," and they're super interesting because they often make words that are opposites! The suffix "-ful" means "full of" something, like how "cheerful" means full of cheer.

slides.text: The suffix -less means 'without.' Careless means without care. Colorless means without color. Notice something amazing: careful and careless are OPPOSITES created from the same base word!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, the suffix "-less" is like the opposite of "-ful," because it means "without" something. So, if "-ful" means "full of care," then "-less" means "without care," making the word "careless"! Isn't it neat how adding these endings can completely change a word and even make an opposite?

slides.text: Try building opposite pairs: hopeful/hopeless, helpful/helpless, thankful/thankless, powerful/powerless, fearful/fearless. Not every word makes both — 'beautiful' exists but not 'beautiless!' Languages have surprises.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is giving us some super examples of how "-ful" and "-less" can make opposite words from the same beginning word, like "hopeful" and "hopeless." It's also pointing out that not *every* word can have both endings, which is kind of like a fun language mystery! We'll get to try building some of these pairs ourselves.

slides.prompt: Build all the opposite pairs you can: words with both -ful and -less. Write them in your vocabulary journal in two columns. Then write 4 pairs of contrasting sentences: 'The grateful child said thank you. The thankless child said nothing.' Make each pair show the difference!
slides.mascot_explanation: Time for the fun activity! We're going to use our word cards to find all the pairs of words that can be made with both "-ful" and "-less," like "helpful" and "helpless." Then, we'll write these pairs down in our journals and create sentences that show how they're opposites, just like the example shows. You've got this!

slides.text: You now know 6 word-building tools: 4 prefixes (un-, re-, pre-, dis-) and 2 suffix pairs (-tion/-ness and -ful/-less). With just these, you can understand hundreds of words! Keep building your word power.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child form correct -ful and -less words, identify opposite pairs, and use them in contrasting sentences?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at everything we've learned! We started with prefixes and now we've added suffixes like "-ful" and "-less," and we can understand so many more words. You did a fantastic job building words and showing how they can be opposites! Keep practicing, and you'll become a word-building superstar!

parent_notes: The opposite-pair discovery (-ful/-less) is a moment of linguistic insight that delights children. Let them discover the pattern rather than telling them directly. Some words only work with one suffix: 'restless' exists but 'restful' is used less commonly. This is a natural feature of English, not an error. The contrasting sentences activity develops sophisticated writing skills.

title: Mixed Numbers Introduction — What is 1 and 1/2?
description: Students are introduced to mixed numbers: numbers that have a whole number part and a fraction part (e.g., 1 1/2, 2 3/4). They build mixed numbers with fraction insets and connect to real-life examples.
instructions:
1. Pose a question: What if we add 3/4 + 2/4? We get 5/4. But 5/4 is more than one whole!
2. Show with insets: 4/4 fills the whole circle with 1/4 left over. That is 1 and 1/4.
3. Define: A mixed number has a whole number part and a fraction part.
4. Practice converting: 5/3 = 1 and 2/3, 7/4 = 1 and 3/4.
5. Connect to real life: recipes (1 1/2 cups), measuring (2 3/4 inches).
6. Build and name mixed numbers with the insets.
materials_needed: Fraction insets (2 complete sets if possible)

slides.heading: Mixed Numbers
slides.subheading: When Fractions Are More Than One Whole
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover page for our math adventure! It's introducing us to something called "Mixed Numbers," and it tells us that sometimes fractions can be bigger than just one whole thing. Isn't it neat that we're going to learn how to talk about amounts that are more than a full pizza or more than a whole cookie?

items: Fraction insets — 2 full circle frames if available (or use paper circles)
slides.setup_instructions: Set out 2 fraction inset frames to show 'more than one whole.' If only one frame is available, use paper fraction circles for the second whole. Have measuring cups nearby for real-world connection.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's get our tools ready for this! We'll need our fraction insets – those are like puzzle pieces that make up a whole circle, and we need two of them so we can show amounts bigger than one whole. We'll also use our math journal and a pencil to draw and write down what we discover, and maybe some measuring cups to see how these numbers look in real life.

slides.text: Let us add: 3/4 + 2/4 = 5/4. But wait — we only have 4 fourths in a whole circle! Place 4 fourth-pieces to fill one circle completely. That is 4/4 = 1 whole. One piece is left over: 1/4. So 5/4 = 1 and 1/4!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to do some adding with fractions! Imagine we have 3 pieces of a pizza cut into fourths, and we add 2 more fourth pieces. That gives us 5 fourths! But since 4 fourths make a whole pizza, we can see that 5 fourths is one whole pizza with one extra fourth left over. So, 5/4 is the same as 1 whole pizza and 1/4 of another pizza!

slides.text: A MIXED NUMBER has a whole number part and a fraction part. 1 and 1/4 is a mixed number: 1 whole and 1 quarter. 5/4 is called an IMPROPER FRACTION: the top number is bigger than the bottom.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide tells us what to call these special numbers. When we have a whole number and a fraction together, like our 1 and 1/4, it's called a "mixed number" because it's a mix of a whole part and a fraction part. The other way we saw it, 5/4, is called an "improper fraction" because the top number (the numerator) is bigger than the bottom number (the denominator).

slides.text: Try 7/3: fill one circle with 3 thirds (= 1 whole), fill another with 3 thirds (= 2 wholes), and 1 third is left. 7/3 = 2 and 1/3. Real life: 'The recipe needs 2 and 1/2 cups of flour. That is 2 full cups plus half a cup.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's another example to help us practice! If we had 7 thirds, we could make two whole circles using 3 thirds in each one, and then we'd have just 1 third left over. So, 7/3 is the same as 2 whole circles and 1/3 of another circle! Think about recipes – sometimes they say you need 2 and a half cups of something, and that's exactly what this looks like.

slides.prompt: Convert these improper fractions to mixed numbers using the insets: 5/4, 7/3, 5/2, 8/5, 9/4, 7/6. Draw each one showing the full circles and leftover pieces. Then find mixed numbers at home: look at recipes, rulers, or measuring cups. Record 3 real-life mixed numbers!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the math magician! You'll use your fraction insets to show what these "improper fractions" look like as "mixed numbers," just like we practiced. After you draw them, try to find some real-life examples of mixed numbers at home, like in a cookbook or on a ruler, and write them down.

slides.text: Mixed numbers are everywhere! When you say 'I am 7 and a half years old' or 'I need 1 and a quarter cups,' you are using mixed numbers. You can now convert between improper fractions and mixed numbers!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child convert at least 4 improper fractions to mixed numbers and explain what a mixed number represents?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You learned that mixed numbers are all around us, from telling your age to measuring things for a craft project. You're now a pro at turning those "improper fractions" into easy-to-understand mixed numbers, and you can spot them everywhere you look!

parent_notes: Mixed numbers are a big conceptual leap. The key insight is that improper fractions and mixed numbers represent the same amount — they are two ways of writing the same thing. Physical manipulation with the insets makes this clear. Do not rush to abstract conversion formulas; let the child build understanding through the materials. Real-world connections (recipes, measurements) make mixed numbers relevant.

title: Parts of a Flower — Detailed Nomenclature
description: Students learn the detailed parts of a flower using the Montessori botany nomenclature cards: petal, sepal, stamen (anther and filament), pistil (stigma, style, ovary). They dissect a real flower to identify each part.
instructions:
1. Show a large diagram of a flower with all parts labeled.
2. Present each part using the three-period lesson: name, recognize, recall.
3. Dissect a real flower: carefully separate petals, sepals, stamen, and pistil.
4. Tape or glue dissected parts to paper and label them.
5. Explain each part's function in reproduction.
6. Complete nomenclature card matching work.
materials_needed: Fresh flowers (lilies, tulips, or other large flowers)

slides.heading: Parts of a Flower
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our exciting flower adventure! It tells us we're going to learn all the special names for the different parts of a flower, which is super important for how plants make new baby plants. Get ready to become a flower expert!

items: 2-3 fresh, large flowers (lilies or tulips work best)
White paper for mounting dissected parts
slides.setup_instructions: Set out flowers, magnifying glass, and nomenclature cards. Prepare white paper with lines for mounting parts. Cover workspace with newspaper for easy cleanup.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the cool stuff we need for our flower investigation! We've got some beautiful fresh flowers, like big, colorful trumpets, and special picture cards that show each flower part. You'll also use a magnifying glass, which is like a superhero tool to see tiny things, and some tape or glue to stick your flower pieces onto paper, along with your science journal to draw in. Make sure you have a grown-up to help you gather everything!

slides.text: A flower is a plant's reproductive organ — it is how plants make seeds! Every part of the flower has a special job. Today we will take a flower apart and name every piece.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part tells us that flowers are like the special 'grown-up' part of a plant, because they're in charge of making seeds so more plants can grow! Think of it like how you might help plant a seed to grow a new flower. We're going to carefully take a real flower apart, like a puzzle, and learn the name for every single piece.

slides.text: The outer green parts are SEPALS — they protected the flower when it was a bud. The colorful parts are PETALS — they attract pollinators like bees. Together, sepals and petals are the 'outside' of the flower.
slides.mascot_explanation: See those green leaves at the very bottom of the flower? Those are called SEPALS, and they hug the flower tightly when it's just a little baby bud, keeping it safe. Then you have the big, bright, colorful parts – those are the PETALS! They are like a flower's fancy outfit, designed to catch the eye of buzzy bees and fluttering butterflies.

slides.text: Inside: the STAMEN is the male part, with a long FILAMENT topped by an ANTHER (the pollen-maker). The PISTIL is the female part in the center, with the STIGMA (sticky top), STYLE (tube), and OVARY (where seeds form) at the bottom.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're looking at the parts inside the flower! The STAMEN is like the boy part, and it has a skinny stick called a FILAMENT with a fuzzy top called an ANTHER, where the golden dust called pollen is made. In the very middle is the PISTIL, the girl part, with a sticky top called the STIGMA, a tube called the STYLE, and a swollen bottom called the OVARY, where tiny seeds will grow.

slides.prompt: Carefully dissect your flower. Separate and identify: sepals, petals, stamens (count them!), and the pistil. Tape each part to white paper and label it. Use the magnifying glass to look at pollen on the anther! In your science journal, draw a labeled diagram of a complete flower.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for the best part – we get to be flower detectives! Carefully pull apart your flower and use your magnifying glass to get a super close look at everything. Try to find all the sepals, petals, and stamens – maybe even count how many stamens your flower has! Then, stick each part onto your paper and write its name, just like a scientist. Don't forget to draw your own amazing flower in your journal!

slides.text: Every flower you see is a tiny factory for making seeds. The colors and smells that make flowers beautiful to us exist to attract pollinators. Tomorrow we will learn about pollination — how pollen gets from one flower to another!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify and name at least 5 parts of a flower (petal, sepal, stamen, pistil, ovary) and explain one function?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You took apart a flower and learned all its secret names, just like a real botanist! Remember how flowers are like tiny factories that make seeds, and how their beautiful colors help attract bees to do their important job? Tomorrow, we'll discover even more about how those bees help make new flowers happen!

parent_notes: Flower dissection is a highlight of Montessori botany. Lilies and tulips are ideal because their parts are large and easy to separate. Avoid composite flowers (daisies, sunflowers) for this first lesson as they are actually clusters of tiny flowers. If fresh flowers are unavailable, use high-resolution printed photos. The nomenclature work follows the Montessori three-period lesson format for learning vocabulary.

title: Botanical Illustration — Drawing Flowers in Detail
description: Students create detailed botanical illustrations of the flowers they dissected in science, focusing on accurate observation, proportion, and labeling in the scientific illustration tradition.
instructions:
1. Show examples of botanical illustrations (historical and modern).
2. Discuss the difference between artistic and scientific drawing: accuracy, proportion, detail.
3. Place a fresh flower specimen next to the child's workspace.
4. The child draws the flower from observation, not imagination.
5. Add fine details: veins in petals, texture of stem, individual stamens.
6. Label all parts with lines and neat print.

slides.heading: Botanical Illustration
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our special art project! It tells us we're going to be drawing flowers, but not just any drawings – we're going to draw them like super-smart scientists do. This means we'll be looking really, really closely at all the tiny parts of a flower.

items: Fresh flower specimen (same type as dissected in science)
Colored pencils (good quality, many greens and colors matching the flower)
Examples of botanical illustrations (printed or in books)
slides.setup_instructions: Set the flower in a small vase at the child's eye level. Display botanical illustration examples. Lay out drawing materials. Good lighting is important for seeing details.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for some amazing flower art! We need a real flower, just like the one we looked at in science, so we can draw it exactly as it is. We'll also need special paper, a couple of different pencils for drawing light and dark lines, and lots of colored pencils to match the flower's true colors. Don't forget the magnifying glass – it's like a super-spy tool for seeing all the tiny details, and we'll look at some cool examples of flower drawings that scientists made a long time ago.

slides.text: For hundreds of years, scientists drew detailed pictures of plants before cameras existed. These botanical illustrations had to be so accurate that another scientist could identify the plant from the drawing alone!
slides.mascot_explanation: Long, long ago, before cameras were even invented, scientists needed a way to show other people exactly what plants looked like. They would draw them super carefully, making sure every leaf and petal was just right. Their drawings were so good that another scientist could look at the picture and know exactly which plant it was, all without even seeing the real thing!

slides.text: The key to botanical drawing is OBSERVATION. Look carefully at your flower. Notice the shape of each petal, how the stem connects, how the stamens are arranged. Draw what you SEE, not what you think a flower looks like.
slides.mascot_explanation: The most important trick for drawing like a scientist is to be a super-duper observer! That means you have to *really* look at your flower. What shape are the petals? How does the stem bend? Where are the little dusty bits inside? You're going to draw exactly what your eyes see, not just what you *think* a flower should look like.

slides.text: Start with a light pencil outline of the overall shape. Then add details: the curve of each petal, the veins, the texture. Finally, color carefully, matching the exact colors you see. Label all the parts you learned in science.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's start drawing! First, use your light pencil to sketch the main shape of the flower, like drawing a faint ghost of it. Then, go back and add all the amazing little details you noticed – the tiny lines on the petals, how the stem feels bumpy or smooth, and all those little parts inside. After that, use your colored pencils to match the colors perfectly, and finally, use your pencil to write the names of the flower's parts next to them.

slides.prompt: Create a botanical illustration of your flower specimen. Draw from observation (look at the real flower, not from memory). Include accurate shapes, proportions, and colors. Use the magnifying glass for tiny details. Label at least 5 parts. Sign and date your illustration.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the scientist-artist! Take your time and really look at your flower, using your magnifying glass to spot all the secrets. Draw its shape, its colors, and all those tiny details you see. Then, find at least five parts of the flower and label them clearly with your pencil, just like we learned. Don't forget to sign your awesome artwork!

slides.text: Botanical illustration combines art and science beautifully. Your drawing is both a work of art and a scientific record. Some of the most famous botanical artists, like Maria Sibylla Merian, changed our understanding of nature through their illustrations.
slides.mastery_check: Does the illustration show accurate observation of the real flower with at least 5 labeled parts and appropriate colors?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! Your drawing is a fantastic piece of art, but it's also like a super-accurate map of your flower that other scientists could use. You combined your amazing drawing skills with careful observation, just like the famous artists who helped us learn so much about nature. You should be really proud of how you captured all those details!

parent_notes: Botanical illustration teaches careful observation — one of the most important scientific skills. Do not worry about artistic perfection; focus on the child's effort to observe accurately. Compare the drawing to the real flower together: 'What details did you capture well? What was hardest to draw?' Maria Sibylla Merian (1647-1717) is a fascinating figure — a woman scientist-artist centuries ahead of her time.

title: Flower Arranging — Care of the Environment
description: Students learn the Montessori practical life skill of flower arranging: selecting, cutting, and arranging flowers in a vase. This develops fine motor skills, aesthetic sense, and care of the environment.
instructions:
1. Show the flower arranging materials and workspace.
2. Demonstrate: choose flowers, trim stems at an angle, remove lower leaves.
3. Show how to arrange: tallest in the center, shorter around the edges.
4. Discuss color and balance.
5. The child creates their own arrangement.
6. Place the arrangement in a prominent spot and discuss care (water changes).

slides.heading: Flower Arranging
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of a special book, and it's telling us all about a super fun activity called "Flower Arranging." It also says "Beauty in the Environment," which means we're going to use flowers to make our space look extra pretty!

items: Assorted flowers (from garden, grocery store, or wildflowers)
Tray, towel, and small water pitcher
slides.setup_instructions: Set up the arranging workspace on a tray. Lay out flowers and greenery. Fill a small pitcher with water. Put the vase on the tray. Wear an apron.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the goodies we need to make our flower masterpiece! We've got pretty flowers and some leafy green stuff called greenery, a vase to put them in, and special scissors for trimming stems. There's also a tray to keep things tidy, a towel for little spills, and a small pitcher for pouring water – like a tiny watering can! Don't forget your apron to keep your clothes clean, and then let's get everything set up on the tray.

slides.text: In Montessori classrooms, children arrange fresh flowers every week. This is part of 'care of the environment' — making our learning space beautiful. Today you will create a flower arrangement.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like a sneak peek into what we're going to do. In Montessori schools, kids do this all the time to help take care of the classroom and make it beautiful for everyone! Today, you get to be the artist and make your very own beautiful flower arrangement.

slides.text: First, fill the vase halfway with water. Choose your flowers. Trim each stem at an angle with the scissors — this helps the flower drink water. Remove any leaves that would be below the water line (they cause bacteria).
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to the fun part of actually making the arrangement! First, we need to fill our vase about halfway with water. Then, pick out your favorite flowers, and using the scissors, carefully cut the bottom of each stem at a slant, like a little ramp – this helps the flower drink up water really well. Make sure to pull off any leaves that will be under the water, because those can make the water yucky.

slides.text: Arrange the flowers: start with the tallest in the center, then add medium flowers around them, and short flowers or greenery around the edges. Step back and look — does it look balanced? Adjust as needed.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about making your flowers look amazing in the vase! Start by putting your tallest flowers right in the middle, like they’re standing up straight and tall. Then, place the medium-sized flowers all around the tall ones, and finally, tuck the shorter flowers or greenery around the very edges. Take a step back and look – does it look nice and balanced, like a pretty picture?

slides.prompt: Create your own flower arrangement following the steps. Choose flowers for color, height, and variety. Trim, arrange, and adjust until you are pleased with the result. Clean up your workspace when finished. Place the arrangement where your family can enjoy it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's your turn to shine! You get to create your very own beautiful flower arrangement. Pick out all the colors and shapes you love, trim those stems like we practiced, and arrange them in your vase until it looks just perfect. When you're all done, make sure to clean up your space, and then find a special spot to put your beautiful creation so everyone can enjoy it!

slides.text: Your arrangement brings beauty to our home! Flower arranging is an art practiced in cultures around the world — from Japanese ikebana to European bouquets. Change the water every other day to keep the flowers fresh.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently trim stems, arrange flowers with attention to height and balance, and clean up the workspace?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that gorgeous flower arrangement you made! You brought so much beauty into our home, just like people have been doing with flowers for a super long time all around the world. To keep your flowers happy and fresh, remember to change the water every two days, like giving them a fresh drink!

parent_notes: Flower arranging is a classic Montessori practical life activity that develops fine motor skills (cutting), aesthetic judgment (color and balance), and responsibility (caring for the arrangement). It also connects to this week's botany lessons. This can become a weekly routine — many children love being responsible for fresh flowers in the home. Grocery store flowers work perfectly.

title: Root Words — The Heart of Word Families
description: Students learn that root words are the base forms from which word families grow. They explore how adding different prefixes and suffixes to the same root creates a family of related words.
instructions:
1. Introduce root words: the core word without any prefix or suffix.
2. Example: 'help' is a root word. Add un- = unhelpful. Add -ful = helpful. Add -less = helpless. Add -er = helper.
3. Build word family trees: start with a root and branch out.
4. Explore roots: play, kind, friend, care, move, work, write.
5. The child creates word family trees in their journal.
6. Discover that some roots come from Latin and Greek.
materials_needed: Prefix and suffix cards from previous lessons

slides.heading: Root Words
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of a book! It tells us we're going to learn about "Root Words" and how they help us grow "Word Family Trees." It's like discovering the secret heart of words!

items: Root word cards: help, play, kind, friend, care, move, work, write, act, build
All prefix cards (un-, re-, pre-, dis-) and suffix cards (-tion, -ness, -ful, -less)
slides.setup_instructions: Write root words on brown cards (like tree trunks). Have all prefix and suffix cards from previous lessons. Prepare large paper for drawing word family trees.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our word adventure. We have "root word cards" – think of them as the seeds for our word trees, with words like 'help' and 'play' on them. Then we have "prefix cards" and "suffix cards" that are like special helpers that attach to the root words to make new words, and we'll use big paper and colorful markers to draw our word trees in our "vocabulary journal." Make sure you have all these things ready!

slides.text: A root word is the simplest form of a word — no prefix, no suffix, just the core meaning. Think of it as the trunk of a tree. When we add prefixes and suffixes, the tree grows branches!
slides.mascot_explanation: This step explains what a root word is. Imagine a big, strong tree trunk – that's our root word! It's the main part of the word that carries the most important meaning. Prefixes are like branches that grow *before* the trunk, and suffixes are like leaves that grow *after* the trunk, adding even more to the word's meaning.

slides.text: Let us grow a tree from the root 'play': replay (play again), playful (full of play), player (one who plays), playground (place to play), playful, misplay. One root creates a whole family!
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we see an example using the root word 'play'! See how adding 're-', '-ful', and '-er' to 'play' makes totally new words like 'replay,' 'playful,' and 'player'? It's like one little seed growing into a whole bunch of different plants, all related to the original 'play' idea.

slides.text: Try 'kind': unkind (not kind), kindness (state of being kind), kindly (in a kind way), kinder, kindest. The root 'kind' carries the meaning through every word in the family.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us another example with the root word 'kind.' Look at how 'un-', '-ness,' and '-ly' change 'kind' into words like 'unkind,' 'kindness,' and 'kindly.' The root 'kind' is still in there, helping us understand what each new word means, just like the trunk of our word tree!

slides.prompt: Create word family trees for 4 root words: draw a tree trunk with the root word, then branches for every word you can make using prefixes, suffixes, or both! Roots: friend, care, move, write. Challenge: can any word have BOTH a prefix AND a suffix (like un-help-ful)?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the word gardener! You'll pick four root words – 'friend,' 'care,' 'move,' and 'write' – and draw a tree trunk for each in your journal. Then, you'll add branches for all the new words you can make by adding prefixes or suffixes, or even both, to those root words. See if you can make super-long words like 'un-help-ful'!

slides.text: When you know a root word, you can figure out the meaning of its entire word family! This is one of the most powerful reading strategies. If you see an unfamiliar word, look for a root you know inside it.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify root words and build word families with at least 4 related words per root?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you've built some amazing word family trees! This slide reminds us that knowing a root word is like having a superpower. If you see a new word you don't know, you can look for a root word you *do* know inside it to help you figure out its meaning. Great job becoming a word detective!

parent_notes: Root word awareness is a bridge to advanced vocabulary. When children understand that 'transport,' 'portable,' and 'export' all contain the Latin root 'port' (to carry), they can decode unfamiliar words independently. At this level, we focus on English root words. Latin and Greek roots will be explored more deeply in upper elementary. The challenge of combining prefix + root + suffix shows word-building mastery.

title: Mixed Numbers — Building and Comparing
description: Students practice building mixed numbers with fraction insets, comparing them, and ordering them from least to greatest. They connect mixed numbers to real-world measurement contexts.
instructions:
1. Review: what is a mixed number? Build 2 and 1/3 with the insets.
2. Compare mixed numbers: Is 1 and 3/4 greater than 2 and 1/4?
3. Strategy: compare whole numbers first, then compare fraction parts.
4. Order a set of mixed numbers from least to greatest.
5. Measure objects to the nearest fraction of an inch (mixed number results).
6. Record all work in the math journal.

slides.heading: Mixed Numbers
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing our exciting math adventure today! We're going to learn all about "mixed numbers," which are like special numbers that have a whole number part and a fraction part all mixed together. Get ready to build and compare them!

items: Fraction insets (2 complete sets for building)
Ruler marked with 1/4 and 1/2 inch increments
5-6 objects to measure (book, pencil, crayon, etc.)
slides.setup_instructions: Set out 2 fraction inset frames. Prepare comparison problems. Gather objects for measuring. Have the ruler ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is our super-duper toolkit for today's lesson! We've got fraction insets – those are like puzzle pieces for fractions that help us build numbers. We also have our math journal and pencil to write everything down, and a special ruler that shows us tiny pieces of an inch, like fourths and halves. Finally, we need some everyday objects, like a book or a pencil, to measure later on – make sure you have a grown-up help you find these things!

slides.text: Build 2 and 1/3 with the insets: fill one circle with 3 thirds (1 whole), fill another with 3 thirds (2 wholes), and place 1 third in a third frame. Two wholes and one-third = 2 and 1/3.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to build our first mixed number! See those circles? We're going to use the fraction pieces to show the number 2 and 1/3. First, fill up two whole circles completely with the fraction pieces – that makes our '2' whole part. Then, take one more fraction piece and put it in a new circle – that's our '1/3' part! So, two full circles and one little piece makes 2 and 1/3.

slides.text: Compare: Which is greater, 1 and 3/4 or 2 and 1/4? Look at the whole numbers first: 1 vs. 2. Since 2 > 1, then 2 and 1/4 is greater, even though 3/4 > 1/4. The whole number matters more!
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is like a friendly math detective game! We need to figure out which number is bigger: 1 and 3/4 or 2 and 1/4. The trick is to look at the big whole numbers first. Is 1 bigger or is 2 bigger? Since 2 is bigger than 1, the number 2 and 1/4 is the winner, even if the fraction part looks smaller sometimes!

slides.text: What if the whole numbers are the same? Compare 3 and 1/4 with 3 and 3/4. Same whole number (3), so look at the fractions: 3/4 > 1/4. So 3 and 3/4 is greater.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, what happens when the whole numbers are the same, like when we compare 3 and 1/4 with 3 and 3/4? Since the whole number '3' is the same in both, we have to look at the fraction pieces! Which is more, 1/4 of a pizza or 3/4 of a pizza? The bigger fraction part means the whole mixed number is bigger, so 3 and 3/4 is the larger number here.

slides.prompt: Compare these pairs (use >, <, or =): 1) 2 1/2 vs 1 3/4, 2) 3 1/3 vs 3 2/3, 3) 4 1/4 vs 3 3/4, 4) 2 2/5 vs 2 3/5. Then order from least to greatest: 1 3/4, 2 1/4, 1 1/2, 2 3/4, 1 1/4. Finally, measure 5 objects to the nearest 1/4 inch — your answers will be mixed numbers!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the math star! You'll compare pairs of mixed numbers using our new tricks – check the whole numbers first, then the fractions if the wholes are the same. Then, you'll put a list of mixed numbers in order from the smallest to the biggest. Finally, use your special ruler to measure five different objects, and write down your answers as mixed numbers. You've got this!

slides.text: Mixed numbers make measurement precise. When you say a pencil is 5 and 3/4 inches long, that is much more accurate than just saying '6 inches.' Fractions are the language of precision!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child compare and order mixed numbers and measure objects to the nearest quarter inch?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the amazing things you did today! You built mixed numbers, you compared them like a pro, and you even used a ruler to measure real objects super accurately. You learned that using fractions in measurements, like saying something is 5 and 3/4 inches long instead of just 'about 6 inches', makes us super precise – just like a scientist! You totally mastered mixed numbers!

parent_notes: Comparing mixed numbers develops number sense with fractions. The 'whole number first' strategy is important but the tricky cases (when whole numbers are the same) require deeper fraction understanding. Measurement is an ideal context for mixed numbers because every real measurement is likely a mixed number. Let the child measure freely around the house for extra practice.

title: Ancient Egypt — Daily Life, Schools, and Social Structure
description: Students explore Egyptian social structure (pharaoh, priests, nobles, scribes, craftspeople, farmers, slaves) and daily life including schools, where only boys from wealthy families learned to read and write.
instructions:
1. Draw the Egyptian social pyramid on the board.
2. Discuss each level: who they were and what they did.
3. Focus on scribes: specially trained writers who kept records.
4. Discuss education: scribal schools were strict, writing was on clay tablets.
5. The child creates a social pyramid diagram with illustrations.
6. Compare Egyptian social structure to modern society.

slides.heading: Egyptian Society
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our adventure book about Ancient Egypt! It tells us we're going to learn all about how people lived back then and how everyone fit into their society, kind of like different jobs in a big city.

slides.setup_instructions: Draw a large triangle on the board or chart paper to introduce the social pyramid concept. Have reference materials ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, time to gather our tools for becoming Egyptian history detectives! We need that picture of the social pyramid to see how everyone was ranked, some big paper and colorful pens to make our own masterpiece, and our history journal with a pencil to write down all our amazing discoveries.

slides.text: Egyptian society was shaped like a pyramid. At the very top: the Pharaoh — ruler of all. Below: priests and nobles. Then: scribes and officials. Below: craftspeople and merchants. At the base: farmers and laborers. At the very bottom: slaves.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us the big picture of Egyptian society. Imagine a giant triangle: the pharaoh, who was like the king, was at the very tippy-top, and then below them were important people like priests and nobles, followed by scribes who were super smart writers, then people who made things, farmers who grew food, and finally, people who had the hardest jobs, like slaves.

slides.text: Most Egyptians were farmers who grew crops in the rich Nile mud. Only about 1 in 100 people could read and write! Scribes were very important — they kept records, wrote letters, and recorded history. To become a scribe, a boy went to school for about 12 years.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, most people in Egypt were farmers, working hard in the dirt near the river to grow food for everyone! It's pretty amazing that only a tiny number of people knew how to read and write, and the ones who did, the scribes, were super important for keeping track of everything, like our teachers do for our grades!

slides.text: Scribal school was tough! Students woke before dawn, practiced writing hieratic (a faster form of hieroglyphics) on pieces of pottery, and were sometimes beaten for mistakes. But a scribe had a good life — no heavy labor, good pay, and the pharaoh's respect.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is telling us about what it was *really* like to be a scribe in training – yikes, it sounds tough! They had to wake up super early and practice writing on broken pottery, and even got in trouble if they made mistakes, but even though school was hard, being a scribe meant you had a good job with lots of respect.

slides.prompt: Draw a large social pyramid in your history journal. Illustrate each level with a figure and label their role. Write 2 sentences about each level describing what they did. At the bottom, write: 'If I lived in Ancient Egypt, I would want to be a _____ because _____.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to create your own Egyptian world! Grab your journal and draw that big pyramid shape, then draw a little picture for each job and write its name, like 'Pharaoh' or 'Farmer,' and write two sentences telling me what they did all day.

slides.text: Egyptian society was very structured — your position was usually determined at birth. How is this similar to or different from our society today? What seems fair? What seems unfair? These are questions worth thinking about.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 4 levels of the Egyptian social pyramid and explain the role of scribes?
slides.mascot_explanation: We've learned that in Egypt, where you started in life pretty much decided your whole life, which is different from today where we have more choices! Think about it: does that seem fair to you, and what parts of our society are more like Egypt's, and what parts are different?

parent_notes: The social pyramid is a simplified model — real Egyptian society had more nuance. The key insight for children is that most people in ancient civilizations were farmers, not pharaohs. The discussion about fairness and social mobility connects history to the child's sense of justice. Handle the topic of slavery age-appropriately: acknowledge it as a historical reality without minimizing its injustice.

title: African Cultures — Music and Storytelling Traditions
description: Students explore African cultural traditions of music (drumming, call-and-response singing) and storytelling (Anansi tales, griots as oral historians). They experience call-and-response music and hear a traditional tale.
instructions:
1. Introduce Africa's rich cultural traditions: over 2,000 languages and countless musical styles.
2. Listen to African drumming and discuss: What instruments do you hear?
3. Practice call-and-response: leader sings/says a phrase, group echoes.
4. Read an Anansi tale (West African trickster spider stories).
5. Discuss griots: West African oral historians who memorized and told the history of their people.
6. The child retells the Anansi tale in their own words.
materials_needed: Audio of African music (phone or computer)

slides.heading: African Cultures
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our adventure book! It tells us we're going to explore the amazing music and stories from Africa. Isn't it exciting to learn about traditions from so far away?

items: Anansi tale book (e.g., 'A Story, A Story' by Gail Haley or 'Anansi the Spider' by Gerald McDermott)
Drum, djembe, or any percussion instrument
slides.setup_instructions: Queue up 2-3 minutes of African drumming music. Have the Anansi book ready. Set out percussion instruments. Display the Africa map.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our explorer kit ready! We need a book about Anansi the spider, which is a super fun story. We also need a drum or any noisy toy to make music with, a device to play some cool African beats, a notebook and pencil for drawing and writing, and a map so we can point to Africa! Go grab all those things with a grown-up's help.

slides.text: Africa has over 2,000 languages and incredibly rich cultural traditions! Music and storytelling are central to African cultures. Drumming communicates messages, celebrates events, and connects communities.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is telling us how important music and stories are in Africa. Imagine a place with thousands of different languages – wow! Drumming is like their special way of talking to each other for big celebrations or just to share news, kind of like how we use our voices but with rhythm!

slides.text: Let us try call-and-response! This is a musical tradition where a leader sings or says a phrase, and everyone echoes it back. Clap a rhythm — the child copies it. Sing a phrase — the child echoes it. This is how songs have been shared for thousands of years.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to be a part of the music! This is called "call-and-response," and it's like a fun game where someone starts a beat or a little song, and then everyone else copies it right back. It's a way people have made music together for a super long time, and it helps everyone feel connected.

slides.text: Griots are West African storytellers who memorize the history of their people — births, deaths, battles, heroes — and pass it down orally from generation to generation. Before writing, griots were the living libraries! Now let us hear an Anansi tale — stories about a clever spider told by griots across West Africa.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide introduces us to something really special called "griots." Think of them as living libraries from long ago in West Africa! They were super smart people who remembered all the important stories and history of their people, like who was brave and what big events happened, and they told these stories out loud so everyone could learn.

slides.prompt: After hearing the Anansi tale, retell it in your own words in your journal. Then draw Anansi. Write: What lesson does this story teach? Compare griots to our books and libraries — how are they similar and different? Practice a call-and-response rhythm pattern.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the storyteller! After we hear the Anansi story, you'll get to tell it in your own words in your notebook, and maybe even draw a picture of Anansi. We'll also think about how griots are like our books today and try out a cool rhythm pattern. You've got this!

slides.text: African storytelling and music traditions have spread around the world. Call-and-response is in jazz, blues, rock, and hip-hop! Anansi tales traveled to the Americas and Caribbean with enslaved people, keeping African culture alive.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the Anansi tale, explain what a griot does, and participate in call-and-response?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we learned so much! That music and those stories from Africa are like seeds that have traveled all over the world and grown into new kinds of music like hip-hop and blues. And Anansi stories are still told today, even in places far from Africa, all thanks to those amazing griots and people sharing them. You did a great job retelling the story and trying out the call-and-response!

parent_notes: This lesson introduces African cultures with respect and depth. Anansi tales are an excellent entry point — they are engaging, funny, and carry moral lessons. The griot tradition connects to the Montessori emphasis on oral history and the Third Great Lesson. If possible, watch a video of a real griot performing. The connection between African and American music (jazz, blues) shows cultural continuity across the diaspora.

title: Read Aloud — An Anansi Tale from West Africa
description: Read a complete Anansi tale aloud, focusing on the trickster archetype, story structure, and the cultural values embedded in the tale. Compare to trickster tales from other cultures.
instructions:
1. Set the scene: Anansi tales come from the Ashanti people of Ghana.
2. Read the story with dramatic voices and expressions.
3. Discuss the trickster archetype: a clever character who uses wits to overcome challenges.
4. Analyze the story structure: problem, clever plan, consequences, lesson.
5. Compare Anansi to other tricksters: Coyote (Native American), Loki (Norse), Br'er Rabbit (American).
6. The child writes or draws their own trickster tale.

slides.heading: Anansi the Trickster
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of a super cool book! It tells us we're going to read a story about a character named Anansi, who is a tricky spider from West Africa. Get ready for an adventure with Anansi!

items: Anansi storybook (or a second Anansi tale if the first was read in culture class)
slides.setup_instructions: Select a different Anansi tale from the culture class if possible, or re-read with deeper analysis. Create a cozy reading spot. Have the map accessible.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for this story! You'll need the Anansi storybook so we can follow along, a special notebook called a reading journal to write and draw in, and some colored pencils for your drawings. We also have a big map to find Ghana, which is where Anansi's stories come from. Make sure you have all these things before we start our adventure!

slides.text: Find Ghana on the map of Africa. The Ashanti people of Ghana created the Anansi stories. Anansi is a spider who uses cleverness to trick larger, stronger animals. He is not always good — sometimes his tricks backfire!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's find Ghana on our map! See this big continent of Africa? Ghana is a country in West Africa, and that's where the Anansi stories started with a group of people called the Ashanti. Anansi is a clever spider who uses his smarts to get what he wants, even from bigger animals, but sometimes his tricks don't work out so well!

slides.text: Read the tale with dramatic expression. Use different voices for different characters. Pause at the clever moments: 'What do you think Anansi will do? Is this a good plan? What might go wrong?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the real fun begins – reading the story! I want you to use your most exciting voices for each character, like a grumpy animal or a sneaky spider. As we read, think about Anansi's plans: What's his problem, and how is he trying to fix it? Let's pause and guess what might happen next!

slides.text: After reading, discuss: 'Anansi is a trickster — a character type found all over the world. Coyote plays tricks in Native American stories. Loki causes trouble in Norse myths. Why do you think every culture has trickster stories?'
slides.mascot_explanation: After we finish the story, we're going to talk about what a "trickster" is. Anansi is a trickster, and he's like other characters in stories from all over the world, like Coyote or Br'er Rabbit. We'll wonder why so many different places have stories about characters who use their brains to play tricks!

slides.prompt: In your reading journal, write about the Anansi tale: What was Anansi's problem? How did he try to solve it? Did his trick work? What lesson does the story teach? Then draw a 3-panel comic strip of your favorite part of the story.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be creative! In your journal, you'll write down Anansi's problem, his clever plan, and if it worked out. Then, pick your very favorite part of the story and draw it as a comic strip with three pictures. You've got this!

slides.text: Trickster tales teach us that cleverness can be both helpful and dangerous. They remind us that brains can be more powerful than brawn — but using tricks on others often has consequences!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child analyze the story structure (problem, plan, consequences) and compare Anansi to another trickster character?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did an amazing job with the Anansi story! We learned that being clever is super important, but sometimes tricks can cause trouble, and it's good to think about what happens after we play a trick. You really figured out Anansi's problem and his plan, and that's what makes these stories so special!

parent_notes: Trickster tales from different cultures make excellent compare-and-contrast material. If the child enjoys Anansi, explore: 'Anansi and the Moss-Covered Rock,' 'Anansi Goes Fishing,' or 'Anansi and the Talking Melon.' The trickster archetype is a sophisticated literary concept accessible through these fun stories. The comic strip activity appeals to visual learners.

title: Suffix Review — Word Building Workshop
description: Students review all four suffixes (-tion, -ness, -ful, -less) through a hands-on word building workshop where they construct words using root cards, prefix cards, and suffix cards simultaneously.
instructions:
1. Review all four suffixes with meanings and examples.
2. Set out all word-building cards: roots, prefixes, and suffixes.
3. Challenge: build the longest word possible (e.g., un-help-ful-ness).
4. Build word equations: root + suffix = new word + meaning.
5. Play a word-building relay game.
6. Create a complete word-parts reference page.

slides.heading: Word Building Workshop
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the title slide for our fun word-building adventure! We're going to become word detectives and learn how to put different word parts together to make new words, just like building with LEGOs.

items: All root word cards from this week
All prefix cards: un-, re-, pre-, dis-
slides.setup_instructions: Spread all cards out on a large surface, organized by type (roots in the center, prefixes on the left, suffixes on the right). Have the vocabulary journal open.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our building supplies ready! See all those cards? We have root word cards – those are the main parts of words. Then we have prefix cards, like "un-" and "re-", which go at the beginning, and suffix cards, like "-tion" and "-ness", which go at the end. You'll also need your journal to write down the cool words we make.
