slides.text: Today we combine everything: roots, prefixes, AND suffixes! Some words have all three: un- (prefix) + thank (root) + -ful (suffix) = unthankful. dis- (prefix) + agree (root) + -ment (suffix) = disagreement.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to put all the pieces together! We've learned about prefixes and suffixes before, but today we're going to use them with root words all at the same time. Think of it like this: a prefix goes first, then the root word, and then a suffix, like "un-"+"happy"+" -ness" making "unhappiness"!

slides.text: Challenge: build the longest real word you can! Can you get prefix + root + suffix + suffix? Like: un- + care + -ful + -ness = uncarefully? Wait — is that a real word? Let us think carefully about which combinations actually work.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for a challenge! Your mission is to build the longest *real* word you possibly can using the cards. You can even try putting a prefix, a root word, and *two* suffixes together! We'll have to think hard about which combinations actually make sense, like a super-long word puzzle.

slides.text: Word Building Relay: Set the timer for 3 minutes. How many real words can you build using the cards? Each word earns a point. Words with prefix + root = 1 point. Root + suffix = 1 point. Prefix + root + suffix = 3 points!
slides.mascot_explanation: This sounds like a super fun game! We're going to set a timer, and you'll race to build as many real words as you can using the cards. We get points for different kinds of words, and the more parts you use, the more points you might get! It’s a race to build, build, build!

slides.prompt: Play the Word Building Relay: build as many real words as possible in 3 minutes. Record each word in your journal with its point value. Then create a 'Word Parts Reference Page': list all 4 prefixes and 4 suffixes with meanings, example words, and an illustration for each.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to play the word-building relay and then create your own word-parts guide! You'll use the cards to build as many words as possible before the timer runs out, writing each one down. After that, you'll make a special page in your journal showing all the prefixes and suffixes, what they mean, and draw a picture for each one.

slides.text: You are now a master word builder! With 4 prefixes, 4 suffixes, and dozens of root words, you can decode and build hundreds of English words. This superpower will help you in every subject and every book you read.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build at least 15 words using various combinations of prefixes, roots, and suffixes?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at you, you're a word-building superstar! You've learned how to combine prefixes, roots, and suffixes to make tons of new words, which is like having a secret code for reading. This amazing skill will help you understand so many more books and everything you learn in school!

parent_notes: This workshop consolidates two weeks of word study. The relay game motivates quantity, but check quality too — ensure the words built are real English words. The reference page becomes a permanent study tool. Common errors: adding -tion to words that do not form real words, or misspelling words that require letter changes (happy + ness = happiness, not happyness). Gentle correction builds spelling awareness.

title: Fraction Review — Addition, Subtraction, and Mixed Numbers
description: Students practice all fraction skills learned so far: adding like fractions, subtracting like fractions, converting improper fractions to mixed numbers, and comparing mixed numbers.
instructions:
1. Warm up: 5 fraction addition problems.
2. Practice: 5 fraction subtraction problems.
3. Convert 4 improper fractions to mixed numbers.
4. Compare 4 pairs of mixed numbers.
5. Solve 3 word problems mixing all skills.
6. Play a fraction board game for fluency.

slides.heading: Fraction Skills Review
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of a book, telling us what exciting math adventure we're going on today! We're going to become super-duper fraction experts by practicing adding, subtracting, changing them into different kinds of numbers, and seeing which ones are bigger or smaller. It's like leveling up your math skills!

items: Dice and a simple game board (or make one)
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a problem set mixing all fraction skills. Keep fraction insets accessible. Create a simple game board where landing on a space requires solving a fraction problem.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool tools we'll need for our fraction fun today. We've got fraction pieces to help us see what fractions look like, a math journal and pencil to write down our answers, and dice and a game board for a super fun way to practice. Make sure you have all these things ready to go before we start our math quest!

slides.text: You have learned 4 fraction skills this quarter. Let us review them all! Skill 1: Adding like fractions (keep the denominator, add numerators). Skill 2: Subtracting (same rule, subtract). Skill 3: Converting improper fractions to mixed numbers. Skill 4: Comparing mixed numbers.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like our friendly teacher reminding us of the awesome fraction superpowers you've already learned! We're going to practice adding fractions, like putting pieces together, and subtracting them, like taking pieces away. We'll also learn how to turn tricky "improper" fractions into mixed numbers, and how to tell which fraction is the biggest slice of the pie!

slides.text: Let us warm up with one of each: Add: 3/8 + 4/8 = 7/8. Subtract: 5/6 − 2/6 = 3/6. Convert: 11/4 = ? (11 ÷ 4 = 2 remainder 3, so 2 and 3/4). Compare: 2 1/3 and 2 2/3 (2 2/3 is greater).
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to warm up our brains with some quick fraction practice, just like stretching before a big game! We'll do one problem for each skill we just talked about: adding, subtracting, turning an improper fraction into a mixed number, and comparing two mixed numbers. Follow along with the examples on the screen – they show you exactly how to solve them!

slides.text: Word problem combining skills: 'I had 7/4 of a pizza (that is 1 and 3/4 pizzas). I ate 2/4. How much is left? First convert 7/4 to a mixed number... or subtract first: 7/4 − 2/4 = 5/4 = 1 and 1/4 pizzas left!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super cool word problem, like a mini-mystery we get to solve using our fraction skills! It's about pizza, and we need to figure out how much pizza is left after someone eats some. The slide shows you two ways to solve it: you can either change the pizza amount first or subtract right away. See how both ways get you the same yummy answer?

slides.prompt: Complete the mixed practice set: 5 addition, 5 subtraction, 4 conversions, 4 comparisons, and 2 word problems. Show all work with pictures. Then play the Fraction Game: roll dice, solve the problem on the space you land on, advance if correct!
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for the main event – our big fraction practice! You'll solve a whole bunch of problems using all the skills we've reviewed, and you even get to draw pictures to show your work. Then, we get to play a super fun board game where you roll the dice and solve fraction problems to move along the path. It's the best way to become a fraction champion!

slides.text: You have built a solid fraction foundation: adding, subtracting, mixed numbers, and comparing. These skills will serve you in every math topic going forward. Fractions are not scary — they are just numbers!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly complete at least 16 of 20 fraction problems across all four skill types?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the amazing things you've done today! You've practiced adding, subtracting, converting, and comparing fractions like a true math whiz. Remember, fractions are just numbers, and you've shown you can handle them like a pro! You've built a super strong foundation for all the awesome math you'll do next.

parent_notes: This review session is critical for consolidation. Note which skill types cause difficulty — that is where more practice is needed. The game format keeps review engaging. If the child excels, introduce improper fractions in addition: '3/4 + 3/4 = 6/4 = 1 and 2/4.' If they struggle, go back to one skill at a time with the insets.

title: Pollination — How Flowers Make Seeds
description: Students learn about pollination: how pollen travels from the anther of one flower to the stigma of another. They explore different pollination methods (wind, insects, birds, bats) and the co-evolution of flowers and pollinators.
instructions:
1. Review flower parts from the previous lesson.
2. Explain pollination: pollen must travel from anther to stigma.
3. Show how bees collect pollen: pollen sticks to their fuzzy bodies.
4. Discuss other pollinators: butterflies, hummingbirds, bats, wind.
5. Demonstrate with a model: use cotton swabs to transfer 'pollen' (colored powder) between flower diagrams.
6. Discuss why pollination matters for food production.
materials_needed: Colored powder or chalk dust (as pollen)

slides.heading: Pollination
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is all about pollination! It's like a special job that flowers need to do so they can make seeds, and we're going to learn all about how they do it.

items: 2 large flower diagrams with labeled parts
Yellow chalk dust or colored powder (as 'pollen')
Pictures of pollinators (bees, butterflies, hummingbirds, bats)
slides.setup_instructions: Set up 2 flower diagrams on the table. Sprinkle 'pollen' (chalk dust) on the anthers of one. Have cotton swabs ready. Display pollinator pictures.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is our super fun science station! We've got two big pictures of flowers, some fluffy cotton swabs that will pretend to be bee tongues, yellow powder that looks like real pollen, and some cool pictures of animals that help flowers. You'll also need your science journal and a magnifying glass to look super close!

slides.text: Remember the parts of a flower? The anther makes pollen (tiny grains that contain the male cells). The stigma is the sticky top of the pistil (the female part). For a seed to form, pollen must travel from an anther to a stigma. This journey is called POLLINATION.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step reminds us what we learned before! Remember the parts of a flower? The anther is where the pollen lives, and the stigma is at the very top of the flower's center part. For a flower to make a seed, that pollen has to travel from the anther to the stigma – that whole trip is called pollination!

slides.text: How does pollen travel? It cannot walk! Pollinators help: bees visit flowers for nectar, and pollen sticks to their fuzzy bodies. When they visit the next flower, some pollen rubs off onto the stigma. Pollination!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, how does that tiny pollen get around? It can't fly by itself! That's where our pollinators come in, like busy bees. When a bee visits a flower to sip nectar, the powdery pollen sticks to its fuzzy body, and when it flies to another flower, some of that pollen rubs off onto the stigma, like magic!

slides.text: Different flowers attract different pollinators: bright red flowers attract hummingbirds, white flowers that open at night attract bats, strong-smelling flowers attract bees. Wind-pollinated plants (like grasses) do not need colorful flowers — they produce clouds of pollen that blow through the air.
slides.mascot_explanation: Different flowers have special ways to get the right visitors. Bright red flowers are like a flashing sign for hummingbirds, while flowers that smell really strong are like a dinner bell for bees. Some flowers even open up at night for bats to visit! Other plants, like grass, just let the wind carry their pollen all over the place.

slides.prompt: Simulate pollination: dip a cotton swab into the 'pollen' on Flower 1's anther, then touch it to Flower 2's stigma. In your science journal, draw the pollination process step by step. Create a chart matching 4 types of pollinators with the flower characteristics that attract them.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to be a pollinator! Gently dip your cotton swab into the yellow "pollen" on the first flower's anther, just like a bee would. Then, carefully touch that pollen onto the sticky stigma of the second flower. After that, in your journal, draw what you just did, and then match up the pictures of the pollinators with the flower clues that attract them.

slides.text: Without pollination, there would be no fruits, no seeds, and no new plants! Bees are especially important — they pollinate about 1 out of every 3 bites of food we eat. That is why protecting pollinators is so important.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the pollination process, name 3 types of pollinators, and describe how flower features attract specific pollinators?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You just helped flowers make seeds, which is super important because without pollination, we wouldn't have yummy fruits and vegetables to eat. Remember how bees help with so many of our foods? That's why taking care of our little pollinator friends is so important!

parent_notes: The pollination simulation makes an abstract process concrete. Real pollen under a magnifying glass is fascinating if available (tap a flower's anther onto dark paper). The co-evolution concept (flowers evolved colors/scents to attract specific pollinators) is a powerful example of how organisms adapt to each other. The food connection (1 in 3 bites from bee pollination) makes this personally relevant.

title: Quadrilaterals — Squares, Rectangles, Parallelograms, Trapezoids
description: Students classify quadrilaterals using the Montessori geometry cabinet. They learn that all quadrilaterals have 4 sides but differ in their parallel sides, equal sides, and right angles.
instructions:
1. Define quadrilateral: any shape with 4 sides (quad = 4, lateral = sides).
2. Present from the geometry cabinet: square, rectangle, parallelogram, rhombus, trapezoid.
3. Classify by properties: parallel sides, equal sides, right angles.
4. Show relationships: a square is a special rectangle, which is a special parallelogram.
5. The child sorts and traces quadrilaterals.
6. Create a quadrilateral family tree showing relationships.

slides.heading: Quadrilaterals
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our adventure book! It tells us we're going to learn all about "Quadrilaterals," and it calls them "The Four-Sided Family." That means we're going to meet some shapes that all have something special in common: they all have four sides!

items: Geometry cabinet quadrilateral drawer (or cardboard cutouts)
slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the quadrilateral shapes from the geometry cabinet. Have geometry sticks ready for construction. Open math journal to a new page titled 'Quadrilaterals.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, get ready to gather our explorer tools! We've got the "Geometry cabinet quadrilateral drawer" – that's where all our special four-sided shapes are hiding. Then we have "Geometry sticks" to build our own shapes, a "Ruler and protractor" to measure things super accurately, and our "Math journal" and "Colored pencils" to draw and write down all our discoveries. Go grab everything, and let's get set up!

slides.text: 'Quad' means 4, 'lateral' means side. A quadrilateral is any shape with exactly 4 sides. But not all quadrilaterals are the same! Let us meet the family members.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like learning the secret code for our shapes! The word "quadrilateral" sounds big, but it just means "four sides" because "quad" means four and "lateral" means sides. So, any shape with four sides is a quadrilateral, but guess what? They aren't all exactly the same, and we're going to meet them one by one!

slides.text: SQUARE: 4 equal sides, 4 right angles. RECTANGLE: 2 pairs of equal sides, 4 right angles. PARALLELOGRAM: 2 pairs of parallel sides, opposite sides equal. RHOMBUS: 4 equal sides, opposite angles equal. TRAPEZOID: exactly 1 pair of parallel sides.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to meet the stars of our show! We have the SQUARE, which has all sides the same length and perfect square corners. Then there's the RECTANGLE, which has two longer sides and two shorter sides, but still perfect square corners. The PARALLELOGRAM looks like a slanted rectangle, with opposite sides parallel and equal. The RHOMBUS is like a squished square, with all sides equal but maybe not square corners. And finally, the TRAPEZOID, which has only one pair of sides that are parallel.

slides.text: Here is the amazing part: a square IS a rectangle (it has 4 right angles). A rectangle IS a parallelogram (it has 2 pairs of parallel sides). So a square is also a parallelogram! It is like saying 'a poodle is a dog is an animal.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't it neat how shapes can be related, just like people in a family? This slide shows us that a square is actually a super special kind of rectangle because it has those perfect square corners. And since rectangles have parallel sides, a rectangle is also a type of parallelogram! So, a square is like a super-duper special parallelogram. It's like how a poodle is a dog, and a dog is an animal!

slides.prompt: Trace each quadrilateral from the geometry cabinet into your math journal. Label each with its name and properties (parallel sides, equal sides, right angles). Build each shape with geometry sticks. Create a 'Quadrilateral Family Tree' showing how the shapes are related.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the artist and builder! Take each shape from the cabinet, trace it carefully in your journal, and write down what makes it special – like how many sides are equal or if it has right angles. Then, use your geometry sticks to build each shape yourself, and finally, draw a family tree to show how these shapes are all connected. You've got this!

slides.text: Quadrilaterals are everywhere: doors (rectangles), tiles (squares), kites (rhombuses), and traffic signs (trapezoids). Now you can name them all and explain what makes each one special!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and identify 5 quadrilaterals and describe at least 2 properties of each?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the amazing four-sided shapes you've explored today! You learned that quadrilaterals are everywhere, from the doors you walk through to cool kite shapes. You can now name them all and tell me what makes each one unique, which is super smart! You totally rocked learning about the four-sided family!

parent_notes: The hierarchical classification of quadrilaterals (a square is a rectangle is a parallelogram) is a challenging concept that parallels biological classification. Use the geometry cabinet pieces physically — have the child place the square inside the rectangle frame to show it 'fits.' The family tree diagram makes the relationships visual. Finding real-world examples reinforces the lesson.

title: African Drumming — Rhythm Patterns and Communication
description: Students explore African drumming traditions, learning that drums were used for communication as well as celebration. They learn 3-4 basic rhythm patterns and practice maintaining a steady beat.
instructions:
1. Discuss how drums were used in Africa: celebrations, communication, storytelling.
2. Show pictures and videos of djembe drumming.
3. Teach basic drumming techniques: bass (center of drum), tone (edge), slap (snap).
4. Learn 3 rhythm patterns of increasing complexity.
5. Practice maintaining a pattern while the parent plays a different one (polyrhythm).
6. Create a drum circle with any available percussion.
materials_needed: Drum or hand drum (or bucket/pot with lid)

slides.heading: African Drumming
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the big title for our adventure! It's telling us we're going to learn all about African drumming, and how it's used for making rhythms, talking to each other, and bringing people together in a community. Get ready to tap your feet!

items: Hand drum, djembe, or improvised drum (overturned bucket)
Device for playing African drumming audio
Rhythm pattern cards (written as: B = bass, T = tone, S = slap, - = rest)
slides.setup_instructions: Set up a drumming space with room to move. Have drums and percussion accessible. Queue up African drumming audio. Write rhythm patterns on cards.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our drumming fun. We need a drum – it could be a special djembe drum, or even just a bucket turned upside down! We also need some other fun things like shakers or sticks to make more sounds, and a way to play some African music. Don't forget your rhythm cards, which have secret codes for drumming!

slides.text: In many African cultures, drums were not just for music — they were for COMMUNICATION! The 'talking drum' of West Africa could imitate the tones of spoken language, sending messages between villages. Drums called people to ceremonies, warned of danger, and celebrated victories.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is super interesting! It tells us that long ago in Africa, drums weren't just for parties. They were like telephones or radios, used to send messages all over! Imagine a drum sending a message to another village – how neat is that?

slides.text: Three basic sounds: BASS — hit the center of the drum with your flat palm (deep, low sound). TONE — hit the edge with your fingers (medium, ringing sound). SLAP — snap your fingers on the edge (sharp, high sound). Practice each separately.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're learning the secret drum language! See those letters? 'B' means to hit the middle of the drum for a deep sound, like a "boom!" 'T' is for hitting the edge with your fingers for a clearer sound, and 'S' is a quick snap for a sharp sound. Try making each sound a few times to get the feel of it.

slides.text: Pattern 1 (simple): BASS-BASS-TONE-TONE. Pattern 2 (medium): BASS-rest-TONE-SLAP-BASS-rest-TONE-SLAP. Pattern 3 (challenge): BASS-TONE-TONE-SLAP-rest-BASS-BASS-TONE. Practice each until you can play it without thinking.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we learn our first drumming songs, called patterns! Pattern 1 is like a simple chant: Boom-Boom-Clap-Clap. Pattern 2 is a little more tricky, with a little pause in there. Pattern 3 is the biggest challenge! Try playing each one slowly until you can do it without even thinking.

slides.prompt: Practice all 3 rhythm patterns until you can play each one smoothly. Then try: you play Pattern 1 while your parent plays Pattern 2 at the same time (polyrhythm!). Listen to how they fit together. Create your own 8-beat pattern and teach it to your parent.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, drummer, this is the exciting part where you get to show off! Practice those patterns until they feel super smooth, then try playing one pattern while a grown-up plays another one at the same time – it's like a drumming conversation! You can even make up your own pattern and teach it to them!

slides.text: Drumming connects us to one of the oldest forms of human music-making. African rhythms influenced jazz, rock, blues, and hip-hop. Every time you hear a drum beat in modern music, you are hearing echoes of Africa!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child maintain a steady 8-beat rhythm pattern and distinguish between bass, tone, and slap sounds?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! This last slide reminds us that drumming is one of the oldest ways people have made music, and it's still with us today in all sorts of music you hear. You learned how to make those cool drum sounds and keep a steady beat, which is awesome!

parent_notes: Drumming is an excellent activity for developing rhythm, coordination, and concentration. If you do not have a drum, upturned buckets, pots, and boxes all work. The polyrhythm experience (two different patterns at once) is a key element of African music and is more challenging than it sounds. Even a minute of successful polyrhythm is an accomplishment. Let the child move and dance while drumming — African music is whole-body expression.

title: Suffix Application — Finding Suffixes in Reading
description: Students apply suffix knowledge while reading independently, identifying suffixed words and analyzing how the suffix changes the base word's meaning and part of speech.
instructions:
1. Review all 4 suffixes quickly.
2. The child reads independently for 15-20 minutes.
3. Flag words with suffixes using sticky notes.
4. After reading, analyze each flagged word: suffix, base word, part of speech change.
5. Write a reading response paragraph.
6. Compare prefix and suffix word-finding from the past two weeks.

slides.heading: Suffix Detective
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like a secret mission briefing for you, a "Suffix Detective"! Your job is to hunt down special word endings called suffixes in the book you're reading. It's going to be so much fun finding these hidden word clues!

items: Suffix reference card from earlier this week
slides.setup_instructions: Set up the reading spot with sticky notes and the suffix reference card. Have the vocabulary journal ready for after reading.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's get our detective gear ready! You'll need your awesome reading book, some sticky notes to mark your finds, your vocabulary journal to write things down, and a pencil. We also need that special suffix reference card we used before, just in case you need a reminder about what our suffixes mean. Make sure everything is set up nicely so you can dive right into your reading!

slides.text: Quick review: -tion means 'the act of' (verb → noun). -ness means 'the state of' (adjective → noun). -ful means 'full of' (noun → adjective). -less means 'without' (noun → adjective). Now find them in your book!
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, detective, time for a quick refresher on our main suspects! Remember, '-tion' means something is happening, like "imagination" is the act of imagining. '-ness' turns an adjective into a noun, like "happiness" is the state of being happy. '-ful' means something is full of something, like "helpful" means full of help, and '-less' means something is without, like "hopeless" means without hope. Keep these in mind as you read!

slides.text: As you read, flag every word with one of our 4 suffixes. Also look for OTHER suffixes we have not studied yet: -ly, -er, -est, -ment, -able. If you find a new one, flag it with a different color!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for your super-spy move while you're reading! As you find words with our four main suffixes, put a sticky note on them. But wait, there's more! If you see any other suffixes we haven't learned yet, like '-ly' or '-er', flag those too, but use a different color sticky note to show they're new discoveries!

slides.text: After reading, go back to your flagged words. In your vocabulary journal, for each word: write the word, underline the suffix, identify the base word, note the part of speech change, and write your own sentence using the word.
slides.mascot_explanation: After you've finished exploring your book, it's time to examine your clues! Open your vocabulary journal. For every word you flagged, write it down, then underline the suffix part. Next, figure out the original word, called the base word, and think about how adding the suffix changed what the word means or what kind of word it is. Finally, write your own sentence using that word!

slides.prompt: Read for 20 minutes, flagging suffix words. Record at least 5 familiar suffixes and 2 unfamiliar suffixes in your journal. Write a reading response paragraph about the chapter. Challenge: did you find any words with BOTH a prefix and a suffix?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the main part of your mission: read your book for about 20 minutes and be on the lookout for those suffix words, marking them with sticky notes. Try to find at least five words with the suffixes we learned and two with new ones to write in your journal. After that, write a short paragraph about what you read. And for a super challenge, see if you can find any words that have both a prefix at the beginning AND a suffix at the end!

slides.text: In two weeks, you have learned 4 prefixes and 4 suffixes. These 8 word parts help you understand thousands of English words! Keep collecting words — your vocabulary journal is becoming an incredible resource.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently identify suffixed words while reading and correctly analyze the suffix, base word, and meaning?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you've done such an amazing job being a suffix detective! In just a short time, you've learned four important prefixes and four important suffixes, and that helps you understand so many words! Your vocabulary journal is like a treasure chest of words, and you're filling it up with incredible discoveries. Keep up the fantastic work!

parent_notes: The transition from studying word parts in isolation to finding them in authentic reading is the critical step. If the child finds fewer suffix words than prefix words, that is normal — suffixes are harder to spot because they often change the spelling of the base word. Finding words with both a prefix AND a suffix (e.g., 'unthankfulness') shows mastery of the word-building concept.

title: Fraction Problem Solving — Real World Applications
description: Students apply all fraction skills to real-world problem solving: cooking (doubling recipes), sharing (equal distribution), measuring (construction projects), and data (survey results expressed as fractions).
instructions:
1. Present real-world contexts where fractions are used.
2. Cooking: A recipe needs 3/4 cup flour. You want to make double. How much flour?
3. Sharing: 3 children share 2 pizzas equally. How much does each get?
4. Measuring: A board is 3 and 1/2 feet long. You cut off 1 and 1/4 feet. How long is it now?
5. The child solves 4 real-world problems and creates 2 of their own.
6. Discuss: Where else do you see fractions in daily life?

slides.heading: Fractions in Real Life
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure! It's telling us that we're going to learn how to use fractions to solve real problems we might see every single day, not just in our math books. Isn't it cool that math can help us with everyday things?

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 6-8 real-world fraction problems on cards. Have measuring cups and ruler available for hands-on exploration. Open math journal.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool tools we'll use for our fraction adventures. We have fraction insets to help us see fractions, measuring cups like grown-ups use for baking, and a ruler for measuring things. We'll also use our math journal and pencil to write down our answers, and those cards have our problems on them!

slides.text: Fractions are not just for math class — they are everywhere! Let us solve real problems. Cooking: 'A cookie recipe calls for 3/4 cup of sugar. You want to make double the recipe. How much sugar?' 3/4 + 3/4 = 6/4 = 1 and 2/4 = 1 and 1/2 cups!
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we're looking at our first real-life problem, and it's all about cooking! Imagine you're baking cookies and the recipe needs 3/4 of a cup of sugar, but you want to make twice as many cookies. You have to figure out how much sugar you'll need in total, which means adding 3/4 and 3/4. The slide shows us the answer is 1 and 1/2 cups – wow, that’s a lot of sugar!

slides.text: Sharing: '3 friends equally share 2 pizzas. How much does each person get?' Each pizza cut into 3 equal pieces = 6 pieces total. Each person gets 2 pieces = 2/3 of a pizza!
slides.mascot_explanation: This next problem is about sharing, which is super important! If three friends want to share two yummy pizzas equally, how much pizza does each friend get? The slide shows us that if you cut each pizza into three slices, that's 6 slices total, and each friend gets 2 slices, so they each get 2/3 of a pizza. Sharing fair and square is how we use fractions!

slides.text: Measuring: 'A shelf is 2 and 3/4 feet long. You need to cut 1 and 1/4 feet off one end. How long is the remaining piece?' 2 3/4 − 1 1/4: whole numbers: 2 − 1 = 1. Fractions: 3/4 − 1/4 = 2/4. Answer: 1 and 2/4 = 1 and 1/2 feet.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to pretend we're building something, like a shelf. This problem says a shelf is 2 and 3/4 feet long, and we need to cut off a piece that's 1 and 1/4 feet. We need to find out how much of the shelf is left, so we're taking away one fraction from another. The slide shows us that after cutting, we’ll have 1 and 1/2 feet remaining.

slides.prompt: Solve these problems showing all work: 1) A recipe needs 2/3 cup butter. You triple it. How much? 2) 4 kids share 3 cakes equally. How much each? 3) A ribbon is 4 1/2 feet. You cut off 2 1/4 feet. How much is left? 4) Create 2 of your own real-world fraction problems and solve them!
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to be the problem solver! This slide gives you four new fraction problems to solve, just like the ones we just looked at, but these are yours to figure out. You'll need to do all the math in your journal, and the really fun part is that you get to make up two of your *own* real-world fraction problems too!

slides.text: Fractions are the math of everyday life: cooking, building, sharing, measuring, music, sports statistics. The more comfortable you are with fractions, the more capable you are in the real world!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child solve real-world fraction problems and create their own meaningful fraction problems?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we've reached the end of our fraction journey for today! This slide reminds us that fractions are everywhere – in baking, building, sharing, and even in sports scores! You've done an amazing job solving problems and even creating your own. Remember how you figured out those tricky measuring and sharing problems? That’s what makes you a super math whiz in the real world!

parent_notes: Real-world application cements fraction understanding. If possible, actually bake something this weekend using fraction measurements — doubling a recipe is the most natural fraction practice imaginable. The measuring cup and ruler make fractions tangible. Creating their own problems demonstrates the highest level of understanding (Bloom's taxonomy: create). Look for fraction moments all week.

title: Africa — Countries, People, and Diversity
description: Students explore Africa's political geography: the 54 countries, diverse peoples and languages, and major cities. They learn that Africa is not a single culture but a continent of incredible diversity.
instructions:
1. Show a political map of Africa: 54 countries!
2. Locate major countries: Egypt, Nigeria, South Africa, Kenya, Ethiopia, Morocco, Congo.
3. Discuss diversity: over 2,000 languages, many religions, vast cultural variety.
4. Learn about major cities: Cairo, Lagos, Johannesburg, Nairobi.
5. The child labels at least 10 countries on a blank Africa map.
6. Research one African country of their choice for a mini-report.

slides.heading: Africa
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our amazing adventure book about Africa! It tells us that Africa is a HUGE continent, and it's not just one place with one kind of person. Instead, it's packed with 54 different countries and so, so many different kinds of people and cultures.

slides.setup_instructions: Display the labeled political map prominently. Provide a blank map for the child's labeling work. Have the atlas accessible for research.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool tools we'll need for our journey! We have a big map of Africa that already has all the country names on it, like a cheat sheet. Then we have a blank map for us to fill in, some colorful pencils to make our map look awesome, an atlas that's like a giant book of maps for looking things up, and our special geography journal and pencil to write down what we learn. You'll need to grab all these things with a grown-up's help!

slides.text: Africa has 54 countries — more than any other continent! It is home to 1.4 billion people who speak over 2,000 languages. Africa is NOT one country or one culture — it is a continent of incredible diversity.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, get this: Africa has 54 countries, which is more than any other continent on Earth! Imagine, all those countries are home to more people than live in all of North America and Europe combined, and they speak over 2,000 different languages. It's super important to remember that Africa isn't just one big place with the same traditions; it's full of amazing variety!

slides.text: Let us find some key countries: Egypt (northeast, along the Nile — we know this one!). Nigeria (West Africa, most populous country — over 200 million people). South Africa (southern tip). Kenya (East Africa, famous for wildlife). Ethiopia (one of the oldest civilizations in Africa).
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going on a treasure hunt to find some really important countries on our big map! See Egypt way up in the northeast, near that famous Nile River? We're also going to find Nigeria in West Africa, which has tons and tons of people, and South Africa all the way at the bottom. We'll also spot Kenya, known for its amazing animals, and Ethiopia, which has a super long history!

slides.text: Major cities: Cairo, Egypt (20 million people — one of the world's largest cities!). Lagos, Nigeria (15 million — growing fast). Johannesburg, South Africa (a major economic center). Nairobi, Kenya (a tech hub called 'Silicon Savannah').
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like looking at the bustling big cities of Africa! We'll find Cairo in Egypt, which is one of the biggest cities in the whole world, with more people than live in many whole countries! Then there's Lagos in Nigeria, which is growing super fast, and Johannesburg in South Africa, a really important place for business. We'll also learn about Nairobi in Kenya, which is becoming a super smart place for technology!

slides.prompt: Label at least 10 African countries on your blank map (including Egypt, Nigeria, South Africa, Kenya, Ethiopia, Morocco, Algeria, Congo, Tanzania, and Ghana). Color each one differently. Then choose one country to research: write 5 facts about it (capital, population, language, one unique feature, one famous landmark).
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to be map explorers and researchers! Grab your blank map and your colored pencils, and let's carefully label at least 10 countries, like Egypt, Nigeria, and South Africa, coloring each one a different color to make it look fantastic. After that, pick one country that sounds interesting, and using your atlas, find five cool facts about it, like its capital city and something special about it.

slides.text: Africa is a continent of superlatives: the longest river, the largest desert, the most languages, the youngest population. It is also the continent where humanity began! Everything connects to the Second Great Lesson — the Coming of Life and then Humans.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate at least 8 African countries on a map and share 3 facts about one country they researched?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You've explored so many amazing things about Africa today. We learned that Africa has more countries than anywhere else, and it's a place bursting with different languages and cultures. Plus, you got to label countries on your own map and become a mini-expert on one of them – that's fantastic work!

parent_notes: This lesson combats the common misconception of Africa as a monolithic entity. Emphasize diversity: Nigeria alone has over 500 languages! The 'Silicon Savannah' reference shows modern Africa as innovative and dynamic. Let the child choose which country to research — personal interest drives deeper learning. If they are drawn to a less well-known country, that is great exploration.

title: Check Apple Mummification Experiment — Results
description: Students check the results of the apple mummification experiment started in Week 10. They observe, compare, measure, and analyze which preservation method worked best, connecting to Egyptian mummification science.
instructions:
1. Retrieve the 4 apple experiment cups from last week.
2. Observe each apple piece: color, size, texture, smell.
3. Measure and compare: which shrank most? Which is best preserved?
4. Record observations in the science journal.
5. Determine the winner: which method best preserved the apple?
6. Connect results to real Egyptian natron mummification.

slides.heading: Mummification Results
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us the title of what we're going to do today: check on our apple mummies! We're going to see how our apples have changed after a whole week in different mixtures. It's like being a detective for science!

items: Camera or phone for documenting results
slides.setup_instructions: Carefully retrieve all 4 cups. Set up an observation station with the science journal, ruler, and magnifying glass. Do NOT discard any samples until all observations are recorded.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our science tools ready! We need our four apple cups from last week – be super careful when you get them. We also need our science journal to write down what we see, a ruler to measure, and a magnifying glass to look at tiny details. This is how real scientists get ready for their investigations!

slides.text: It has been one week since we started our mummification experiment! Let us check our apple 'mummies.' Remember our cups: 1) Control (nothing), 2) Salt only, 3) Baking soda only, 4) Salt + Baking soda (Natron).
slides.mascot_explanation: It's been a whole week, so it's time to check on our apple pieces! Remember we put them in four different cups: one with nothing, one with just salt, one with just baking soda, and one with a mix of salt and baking soda, which is like the special stuff the ancient Egyptians used called natron. Let's see what happened to each one!

slides.text: For each apple piece, observe and record: Color — has it changed? How? Size — has it shrunk? Measure it! Texture — is it soft, hard, wrinkled, firm? Smell — does it smell fresh, rotten, or neutral? Use the magnifying glass for details.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to be super observers! For each apple piece, look closely at its color – did it turn brown or stay fresh? See if it got smaller and measure it with your ruler. Feel its texture – is it squishy or hard? And give it a gentle sniff – does it smell yucky or okay? The magnifying glass will help you see even more details!

slides.text: Compare your results to your predictions. Which method preserved the apple best? The salt + baking soda mix (like Egyptian natron) should work best because it draws moisture out. The control piece should be the most decayed.
slides.mascot_explanation: After you've looked at all the apples, let's think about which one looks the best preserved. Remember how we talked about salt and baking soda drying things out? The apple with the salt and baking soda mix should look the most like it did when we started, and the one with nothing should look pretty yucky.

slides.prompt: Record all observations in a data table in your science journal: columns for each cup, rows for color, size, texture, smell, and 'preservation rating' (1-10). Draw or photograph each sample. Write a conclusion: Which method worked best? Why? How does this explain Egyptian mummification?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the important part: writing it all down! In your science journal, make a chart to record all your notes about color, size, texture, and smell for each apple cup. You can even draw a picture or take a photo of each one! Then, decide which method worked best and write down why you think that is, connecting it to how the Egyptians preserved bodies.

slides.text: The Egyptians figured out thousands of years ago that salt draws out moisture and prevents decay. This is the same science behind beef jerky, pickles, and preserved fish! Science connects ancient wisdom to modern life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child record accurate observations, rank the preservation methods, and explain why the natron mixture works?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You looked at all your apple mummies, recorded your amazing observations, and figured out which method worked best. Just like the ancient Egyptians discovered thousands of years ago, using salt and other drying agents is a super smart way to keep things from spoiling, and that's the same science we see in things like pickles and jerky today!

parent_notes: This is the payoff for the Week 10 experiment — children are always excited to see the results. The control apple should be significantly more decayed than the treated ones, and the salt+baking soda mix should be best preserved. If results are unclear, extend the experiment another week. This is real scientific practice: hypothesis, experiment, observation, conclusion. Take photos for the portfolio!

slides.text: Egypt's story is winding down in our read-aloud, but its influence lives on. Next week, we travel east to Ancient India — another river civilization with its own incredible story!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child narrate the chapter and make at least one meaningful connection between the reading and another subject?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we've learned so much about ancient Egypt, and your journal entries show how much you've figured out! We're going to finish up our Egypt story soon, but guess what? Next week, we're traveling to a whole new place: ancient India! It's another amazing civilization with its own fascinating history along a big river.

parent_notes: The connection-making activity is a sophisticated thinking skill. Help the child see links: geography shaped Egypt's isolation (desert barriers), the social pyramid explains who built the monuments (farmers during flood season), trade brought new ideas. These cross-subject connections are the heart of Montessori cosmic education. If the child struggles to make connections, model one and then ask them to find another.
